pullRequest.title: Create a BasicContainer Resource as an ArchivalObject.
pullRequest.bodyText:
Create a BasicContainer Resource as an ArchivalObject.

JIRA Ticket:  https://jira.lyrasis.org/browse/FCREPO-3030

Other Relevant Links (Mailing list discussion, related pull requests, etc.)

What does this Pull Request do?
This PR enables the user to create an Archival Object and to nest resources within them.  Resources nested within an Archival Object will appear within the OCFL object associated with the Archival Object resource.
What's new?
Link:<http://fedora.info/definitions/v4/repository#ArchivalGroup>;rel="type" header is now supported on new containers requests.  409 Conflict is returned when trying to nested and ArchivalGroup within another ArchivalGroup.  Also 400 Bad Request is returned when trying to create a binary  with the AG header.
Integration tests cover the above tests.
How should this be tested?
# create the archival resource: 
curl -u fedoraAdmin:fedoraAdmin http://localhost:8080/rest/archival-group -H'Link: <http://www.w3.org/ns/ldp#BasicContainer>;rel="type"'  -H'Link: <http://fedora.info/definitions/v4/repository#ArchivalGroup>;rel="type"' -v  -H "Content-Type: text/turtle"  -X PUT --data "<> <http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/title> 'My Test RDF'"

# nest a resource within it
curl -u fedoraAdmin:fedoraAdmin http://localhost:8080/rest/archival-group/child -H'Link: <http://www.w3.org/ns/ldp#BasicContainer>;rel="type"'   -v  -H "Content-Type: text/turtle"  -X PUT --data "<> <http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/title> 'My Test RDF'"

# verify the results
tree <path to ocfl storage root>

# try to nest an archival group (409)
curl -u fedoraAdmin:fedoraAdmin http://localhost:8080/rest/archival-group/child2 -H'Link: <http://www.w3.org/ns/ldp#BasicContainer>;rel="type"'  -H'Link: <http://fedora.info/definitions/v4/repository#ArchivalGroup>;rel="type"' -v  -H "Content-Type: text/turtle"  -X PUT --data "<> <http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/title> 'My Test RDF'"

# try to create a binary with the AG link header (400)

 curl -u fedoraAdmin:fedoraAdmin http://localhost:8080/rest/binary -H'Link: <http://fedora.info/definitions/v4/repository#ArchivalGroup>;rel="type"' -H "Link: <http://www.w3.org/ns/ldp#NonRDFSource>; rel=type" -v -H "Content-Type: text/plain"  -X PUT --data-binary "test"


Additional Notes:
Any additional information that you think would be helpful when reviewing this PR.
Interested parties
Tag (@ mention) interested parties or, if unsure, @fcrepo4/committers

Could you rename this to represent that it is ensuring that the AG link is NOT present? Might even want to scope it to binaries. Just suggesting this since I was reading it as the opposite of what it does.

remove "LDP" here and in the other tests, its in the fcrepo namespace
I feel like this might be too low level of a check for FedoraLdpIT, it should be interacting against the fedora API.

My understanding is that text/plain is considered a RDF type in fedora, for instance if I do:
curl -ufedoraAdmin:fedoraAdmin -XPUT -H"Content-type: text/plain" --data-binary "@text.txt" http://localhost:8080/rest/somebinary
I get
RDF was not parsable: [line: 1, col: 7 ] Bad character in IRI (space): <?xml[space]...>
If you step through @post, you can see that it is picking this up as a container creation request. It is returning 400 because the body of the request is not valid RDF, rather than because of the AG type.
The easiest way to fix this would be to provide the NonRdfSource link header, or use a different content type.

nodes.bodyText: space

If you update CreateRdfSourceOperationBuilder to override relaxedProperties like it does the other properties in there (it should be there for consistency anyways), then you could get back a CreateRdfSourceOperationBuilder directly and not need to cast down below. You could probably also use var here, but that doesn't matter too much.
This could produce an NPE since the getTypes at line 153 can return null if no link headers are present

I'd suggest updating CreateRdfSourceOperationBuilder to override build() to have a return type of CreateRdfSourceOperation instead. You can see any example of this in NonRdfSourceOperationBuilder
Also, there's an extra space after the ='s here and in the next test.
is there a valid case when operation.getResourceId() would be null?
What is the scenario in which this would be thrown? It might be good to document why its okay for the resource to now be found.

Data model validation feels like it might make sense to take place at the kernel level rather than persistence impl. It would span multiple persistence impls and would potentially be much cheaper to validate since we could check against indexes more easily, and likely already need other "is this parent okay?" checks, like preventing using a binary as a parent. In that case we would presumably also not have to catch persistence errors in fcrepo-http-commons.
Not sure if it makes sense to move it at this point or not, wanted to bring up the point though to see what you think
